newsitem.title: GERMANY: Weak German economy hits Krupp profits.
newsitem.headline: Weak German economy hits Krupp profits.

text.p: German steel and engineering group Fried. Krupp AG Hoesch-Krupp said Wednesday its profits tumbled 17 percent in the first half of 1996 as the weak German economy hurt the group's steel business.

Pre-tax earnings fell to 185 million marks ($124.2 million) in the first six months of the year, from 223 million marks ($149.7 million) in the year-ago period, even though all six of its business divisions were profitable.
Sales edged up 1 percent to 11.7 billion marks and orders rose 2 percent to 12.7 billion marks ($8.5 billion).

"The decline is a result of the unsatisfactory economic development during the period under review," Krupp said. "The drop in earnings in the steel sector and related industries could be only partially offset."

Krupp warned that business in the second half of the year would not recover as strongly as previously thought. The company's shares fell 2.7 percent to 214 marks ($143.67) on the Frankfurt stock exchange at midday.
The market took Krupp's statement as a profit warning, which also put pressure on shares in Thyssen AG, Germany's biggest steel maker.

Demand for steel in Europe in the first half of the year was well below year-earlier levels and put pressure on steel prices. Sales and turnover in the stainless steel division rose because of acquisitions, particularly the takeover of a majority stake in Italy's Acciai Speciali Terni.
Revenue rose 43 percent to 2.8 billion marks ($1.87 billion) and orders grew 35 percent to 2.5 billion marks ($1.68 billion), but Krupp said prices of flat steel products were not satisfactory.
Krupp said sales in the quality steel and sectional steel division fell 14 percent to 2.4 billion marks ($1.6 billion) and orders dropped 21 percent to 2.5 billion marks ($1.68 billion).

Engineering sales rose 8 percent to 1.4 billion marks ($939.9 million), but orders fell 8 percent because of divestments in the sector. Orders in the synthetics group, a subdivision of the engineering division, surpassed year-earlier levels.
Caterpillar Inc. will buy its Krupp MaK Maschinenbau engineering subsidiary, a leading maker of large diesel engines. It said the deal would close in the next few months.

Plant construction turnover surged 35 percent to 789 million marks ($529.7 million), while orders in the division jumped 81 percent because of the acquisition of Dortmund-based Uhde GmbH. Krupp said the takeover would improve its position in Asian and Latin American markets.

Sales in the processing division fell 10 percent to 1.3 billion marks ($872.8 million) and orders fell 18 percent to 1.4 billion marks ($939.9 million). Krupp said orders were unsatisfactory due to weakness in the car industry.
The weak steel business also hurt the trading and services division, where revenue slid 11 percent to 2.9 billion marks ($1.9 billion). Orders fell 10 percent to 3.1 billion marks ($2.1 billion).
